data.text: Contents
Introduction
This policy is intended to safeguard patients and staff by defining best practice for all disciplines involved in the delivery of anti-cancer cytotoxic chemotherapy.

Cytotoxic drugs are defined as all drugs with direct anti-tumour activity including conventional anticancer drugs, monoclonal antibodies, targeted treatments (e.g. Tyrosine Kinase Inhibitors) and drugs such as Thalidomide.
Scope
The purpose of this document is to:
Support the safe prescribing and screening of anti-cancer cytotoxic chemotherapy for children's services in MSE Trust;

Guide staff delivering anti-cancer chemotherapy to paediatric patients with malignant disease. It does not deal with cytotoxic chemotherapy specifically for immunosuppressive purposes, or for the treatment of non-malignant disease but similar principles must apply.
Definitions

table_items.text: Children and Young Person Cancer Network Co-ordinating Group

data.text: Role and responsibilities within the Trust
MSE Patient Safety & Quality Group
Receiving exception reports and taking action in response to issues raised from Medicines Assurance Group and/or department of pharmacy.
MSE Medicines Assurance Group
Ensuring the effective implementation, use and timely review of this policy;
Ensuring that monitoring arrangements are appropriately performed by the Site Medicines Optimisation and Safety Groups (MOSG);

Where necessary, escalating concerns to the Chief Nursing Officer, site Director of Nursing, Deputy Director of Nursing for Paediatrics or Chief Medical Officer, site Medical Director, Clinical Director for Paediatrics as appropriate;
Exception reporting to the MSE Patient Safety & Quality Group on developments, concerns and progress concerning paediatric chemotherapy.
Site Medicines Optimisation and Safety Group (MOSG)
Monitoring this policy through incident reports;
Escalating issues to site divisional governance groups and MAG as appropriate.
Chief Executive

As the Trust's Accountable Officer has overall responsibility for ensuring the Trust has robust, complete and up to date documents in place to govern and guide activities so that legal and national requirements are met.
Chief Medical Officer
Ensuring that there is policy compliance and liaising with the site Medical Directors that the service is operating effectively;
Ensuring sufficient resources are in place to implement this policy
Ensuring any escalated paediatric chemotherapy issues involving professions they oversee are appropriately managed corporately.
Site Medical Directors & Clinical Director for Paediatrics
Appointing the Lead and Deputy Clinicians overseeing paediatric chemotherapy and agreeing their list of responsibilities;
Ensuring that there is policy compliance on site by all professions they oversee and that the service is operating effectively;
Ensuring any escalated paediatric chemotherapy issues involving professions they oversee are appropriately managed corporately.
Chief Nursing Officer
Ensuring that there is policy compliance and liaising with the Deputy/ Chief Pharmacist that the service is operating effectively;
Ensuring sufficient resources are in place to implement this policy;
Ensuring any escalated paediatric chemotherapy issues involving professions they oversee are appropriately managed corporately.
Site Director of Nursing & Deputy Director of Nursing for Paediatrics
Ensuring that there is policy compliance on site by all professions they oversee and that the service is operating effectively;
Ensuring any escalated paediatric chemotherapy issues involving professions they oversee are appropriately managed corporately;
Ensuring sufficient resources are in place to implement this policy;
Chief Pharmacist
Setting the overall framework and policy standards for paediatric chemotherapy across the organisation, in line with regulatory and best practice guidance;
Ensuring a monitoring process exists and functions for policy standard.
MSE Paediatric Oncology Multidisciplinary Team (MDT)
Providing treatment support for all paediatric cancer patients diagnosed between the ages of 0-16 years;
Providing systematic follow up of patients that have completed treatment
Co-ordinating care between PTC and POSCU;
Participating in network agreed audits to monitor implementation of local guidelines;

Ensuring that follow-up and investigation of paediatric chemotherapy incidents is completed in accordance with Trust policies for incident management (MSEPO- 19014 & 19015, and medication errors MSEPO-20206.
Lead Clinician (Consultant Paediatrician) as Head of POSCU Service and associate member of CCLG
Ensuring that all staff involved in delivering chemotherapy to children under the governance of the MDT have undertaken the agreed training;
Ensuring chemotherapy prescriptions are written one week prior to clinic in conjunction with the deputy lead clinician, lead nurse and designated pharmacist.
Ensuring that follow-up and investigation of paediatric chemotherapy incidents is completed in accordance with Trust policies for incident management (MSEPO-
19014 & 19015, and medication errors MSEPO-20206;

The Lead Clinician may delegate aspects of the role to the Deputy Lead Clinician (an Associate Specialist in Paediatrics with an interest in paediatric oncology), though overall responsibility remains with them.
Lead Nurse – Paediatric Oncology and Chemotherapy Trained Nurse;
Providing professional leadership for nursing services for paediatric chemotherapy management.
Designated Pharmacist
Ensuring the safe and effective provision of chemotherapy.
Decision to treat and treatment plan
Following referral to the appropriate PTC the decision to treat a patient with chemotherapy should be made by a cancer specialist (consultant) at that centre.
The patient should be discussed at an appropriate MDT, usually the paediatric oncology MDT.

All patients should have a treatment plan for each course of chemotherapy that they undergo. A copy of this treatment plan must be readily accessible to health professionals e.g. kept in the patient's local case notes.
Authority to prescribe chemotherapy
Paediatric IntraTHECAL Chemotherapy must NEVER by prescribed / dispensed / administered in MSE Trust.
The following healthcare professionals can be authorised to prescribe chemotherapy provided they have completed the CYPCNCG agreed training:
Consultants
All other doctors must NOT prescribe or transcribe parenteral or oral chemotherapy. A register of authorised prescribers is held by pharmacy (appendix 1).
Prescribing a cycle of chemotherapy

Each cycle of chemotherapy, including supportive treatment, must be prescribed on a specific prescription chart. Always refer to the original treatment protocol when completing a chemotherapy prescription and take note if dose modifications are required because of age or previous toxicity.
POSCU acceptable regimens
7.2.1  Chemotherapy  should  only  be  prescribed  if  the  regimen  is  on  the  CYPCNCG agreed list which is available in electronic form from the PTC.
Prescription requirements:
The patient's name, date of birth, unit number, consultant, allergies, current weight and body surface area;
Ward or department where drugs are to be given;
Regime and week of treatment;
Date;
Approved drug name. If handwritten print clearly in full, using block capital letters, the names of all drugs prescribed. Never use abbreviations;
Dose: ensure correct dose is calculated, referring to dose modification details in protocol;
Route and method of administration clearly stated.
Signed and dated by the prescriber;
Include any other appropriate information if required to contribute to safe and effective medicine administration.
Pharmacist screening
7.4.1  All cytotoxic prescriptions must be clinically screened by a suitably trained pharmacist prior to dispensing of parenteral and oral chemotherapy.
Incident reporting

7.5.1  All detected incidents must be reported on the Trust Incident Reporting system and managed in accordance with Trust policies for incident management (MSEPO- 19014 & 19015, and medication errors MSEPO-20206.
Training Requirements
CYPCNCG training:

Medical staff that are competent to prescribe chemotherapy should have at least one year experience at a tertiary children's cancer centre/PTC or equivalent. They must attend an annual update from tertiary centre to update competencies.

Nursing staff attend structured chemotherapy training delivered by tertiary centres e.g. GOSH/UCLH- PTC. Chemo-work to be completed and signed off before nursing staff are declared competent to administer chemotherapy. There is a national chemo passport which can be transferred across Trusts from end of the year.
Good Clinical Practice (GCP) certificate which is updated every two years which the medical staff, nursing staff and pharmacy staff dealing with chemotherapy and trials should keep up to date.
Monitoring and Audit
Outlined below is the Trust's process of monitoring compliance with, and the effectiveness of the document's main points.

table_items.text: Aspect of compliance or effectiveness being monitored
Individual department responsible for the monitoring
Group / Committee / forum which will receive the findings/monitoring report
Committee / individual responsible for ensuring the actions are completed
Paediatric Oncology MDT Site Medicines Optimisation & Safety Group
Paediatric Specialty Governance Group. Medicines Assurance Group.

data.text: Approval and Implementation

All policies, procedures and guidelines will be approved by Medicines Assurance Group, which is the specialist group with the authority to approve local medication documents. These will then be forwarded to the Document control team for submission and ratification by the Joint Document Management Group.
It is the author's responsibility to inform all prescribers, nursing and pharmacy of the approved policy documents when they are uploaded to the Trust's Intranets.
Equality impact assessment
The Trust is committed to the provision of a service that is fair, accessible and meets the needs of all individuals.
(Refer to appendix 2)
References
Children's Cancer Measures, Manual for Cancer Services Version 3.0 (2013), National Cancer Peer Review Programme, National Cancer Action Team
